name: 2021 Easel Updates: Year in Review
description:
Ben here from the Easel team! 2021 has been a really big year for Inventables, especially for - Easel. Take a look at some of the updates you might've already seen this year, or one's you might not know about! You can read the long list below, or just check out the video instead. Most of these features are linked here in the Features and Tools Menu, so you can check them out directly. If you have feedback for us, please use the form at the bottom of this post.

[![VIDEO](https://i.ytimg.com/vi/_4UDeOkYz5U/maxresdefault.jpg)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_4UDeOkYz5U)
[Video Link](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_4UDeOkYz5U)

We can't wait to show you what we have coming, and to see what you'll be making and selling in 2022. 

Updates we've launched in 2021 for Easel Pro

-   Launched the Pro Design Library

-   Toolpath Optimizations for V-Carving

-   Launched Machine Profiles for saved machines

-   Tiling for large materials with custom tile sizes

-   Ramping of Plunge Moves

-   Project Labels in Beta

-   Recommended cut settings for XCP in Easel

-   A new planing project for the X Carve Pro

-   Improvements to the Intro Project for better onboarding

-   Custom defaults for new projects in early access

-   Additional carve below the material

Updates we've launched in 2021 for Easel Free

-   3rd Party Machines Catalog launched: Easier setup process with many 3rd party machines profile defaults. 

-   Re-ordering of Workpieces: Click and drag workpieces to re-arrange

-   Rapid Retracts: Decrease overall carve time to make you more productive

-   Improved Safety Heights: Greatly reduces the risk of running into a clamp

-   The Features and tools menu : Get more information about Easel features plus see new ones added and provide feedback about the features which is sent directly to the Easel Developers!

-   Toolpath improvements for pockets, and profiles: Speed up carving time with optimized tool paths specifically for pockets and profiles

-   Easel Security Updates for all users

-   3rd Party Connections Improved

-   Better control of simulations: Show and hide materials/wasteboard and uncut areas which is helpful for sending renders to clients for project proofing.

-   New Machine Control interface in Beta

-   Easier GCode download: Direct links added in the project menu with an improved interface.

-   Better tabs placement - Tabs are not placed in spots which are hard to remove

name: Adding points to a shape
description:
Adjust and edit your designs in Easel with more options. Add a point to an existing shape without having to re-create it with the pen tool.

##How it works
1. Select your volume on the 2d editor.
2. Enter edit mode (`e` on the keyboard, double-clicking the volume or clicking the edit button).
3. Drag your cursor along the path of the shape and observe a potential point appear.
4. Click on the location you would like to add the point.
5. Drag/edit the new point as needed.

 ![Add point demo](https://easel-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/features/add-point/addpt.gif)


##Issues
Working with extremely large or complicated shapes with a lot of points will degrade performance in Easel. 

* Volumes with less than 1k points should receive no noticeable impact on performance. 
* Volumes with 8k+ points will have up to a few seconds delay in the edit actions.

name: Additional Cut Depth
description:
Easel comes with a very useful feature where you can have some shapes be cut deeper than others. This is helpful if your wasteboard is not perfectly parallel to gantry and you want shapes on one side cut deeper than other. It can also be used to make sure certain cuts go through. Another great use case is when you didn't cut all the way through - instead of running the entire carve again you can duplicate the workpiece and add additional depth just to the shapes that didn't cut, deleting or covering up other ones.

To use this feature change your Shape/Cut panel to Cut. For outline cuts that go as deep as your material the Add Depth will show right below the depth slider.

This feature respects tabs so you don't need to adjust tabs - tabs are omitted from additional depth cuts.

![cut_depth](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/664346/141369444-635ee205-5e02-4d8f-8e34-9b23c2c3796a.png)

name: Automatic Cut Settings
description:
## Summary
The Easel team has re-designed custom cut settings to be more flexible and easier to use. Here's what changed: 

1. Toolbox bits and materials are more flexible
  - Custom bits and materials can be edited and deleted ![](https://easel-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/features/cut_settings/edit+bit.png)
  - Custom materials have optional dimensions to save you time inputting commonly-used sizes ![](https://easel-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/features/cut_settings/edit+material.png)
2. Toolbox contains a Cut Settings tab 
  - Shows you your saved settings ![](https://easel-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/features/cut_settings/view+cut+settings.png)
  - Saved settings can be edited and deleted
  - New settings can be created ![](https://easel-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/features/cut_settings/add+cut+setting.png)
3. Recommended and Custom cut settings have been replaced by Automatic and Manual modes ![](https://easel-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/features/cut_settings/cut+settings+dropdown.png)
  - Each workpiece can be set to Automatic or Manual mode
  - Workpieces default to Automatic mode
4. In Automatic mode, Easel applies the best cut settings for your bit-material combination
  - Your saved settings have priority over Inventables defaults
  - The cut settings drop-down menu tells you where the current settings come from
5. In Manual mode, you provide cut settings for the workpiece and Easel does not change them

We hope these changes make it easier for you to set the cut settings you want and predict how Easel will use them!  

Please note that an Easel Pro subscription (or use of a Free Day) is required to carve using Toolbox cut settings, custom bits or custom materials.

  2. Toolbox contains a Cut Settings tab

Please note that an Easel Pro subscription (or use of a Free Day) is required to carve using Toolbox cut settings, custom bits or custom materials.

name: Easel Toolbox
description:
> With Easel Toolbox, you can save time by storing custom bits and materials for quick and easy set-up. In time, your carve settings and post-carve feedback will help Easel calculate better settings for all users.

*Note: Easel Pro subscribers can take full advantage of the Easel Toolbox by using [Easel Pro’s stored cut settings feature](https://easel.inventables.com/features/stored-cut-settings). Bits and materials in your Easel Pro Toolbox with stored custom cut settings will auto-populate for your projects. This streamlines the carve set-up process and improves your project workflow.*

Adding Bits to Your Toolbox
---------------------------

### Adding a custom bit

Both Easel and Easel Pro users can add and save custom bits into their Toolbox. Only Easel Pro subscribers, Easel Pro day pass users, and Easel Pro free day users can carve with custom bits in their Toolbox.

1.  Once you're logged into Easel, click on the Easel icon in the top left corner to open the **Account** pop-up. Click on the **Toolbox** tab.

2.  Select Bits from the top navigation.
![Open Toolbox](https://inventablesprod.s3.amazonaws.com/general_images/features/mbc/MBC_Bits-1accessToolboxUse.gif) 
3.  Click the **Add Bit** button in the top right corner. Select *Custom* from the dropdown menu. 
![Open Toolbox](https://inventablesprod.s3.amazonaws.com/general_images/features/mbc/MBC_Bits-2addcustombit.gif)
4.  Type in a custom name for your bit. Select your bit type *(Upcut, Straight Cut, Downcut, V)* and enter the bit's cutting diameter. 
*If you are adding a v-bit, enter the angle of the v-bit.*
![Open Toolbox](https://inventablesprod.s3.amazonaws.com/general_images/features/mbc/MBC_Bits-3entercustombitsettings.gif)
5.  Click **Save** to add the bit to your Toolbox.

6.  Close the Account pop-up when finished to navigate to your project. 

7.  Bits added to your Toolbox automatically appear in the bit dropdown menu when you are choosing a bit for your project.
![Open Toolbox](https://inventablesprod.s3.amazonaws.com/general_images/features/mbc/MBC_Bits-4closemodulechoose.gif)


### Adding an Inventables bit

Both Easel and Easel Pro users can add bits from the Inventables store into their Toolbox. Easel and Easel Pro users can carve with any Inventables bits in their Toolbox.

1.  Once you're logged into Easel, click on the Easel icon in the top right corner to open the **Account** pop-up. Click on the **Toolbox** tab.

2.  Select **Bits** from the top navigation.

3.  Click the **Add Bit** button in the top right corner.

4.  Select the *Inventables* for the type of bit you would like to add. Use the filters to help narrow down results and locate your bit. 
![Add Inventables bit](https://inventablesprod.s3.amazonaws.com/general_images/features/mbc/MBC_Bits-5addinventablesbit-min.gif)
5.  Click **Save** to add the bit to your Toolbox.

6.  Close the Account pop-up when finished to navigate to your project. 

7.  Bits added to your Toolbox automatically appear in the bit dropdown menu when you are choosing a bit for your project.

### Carving with a bit from your Toolbox (Easel Pro feature)

Bits added to your Toolbox automatically appear in the bit dropdown menu when you are choosing a bit for your project. 

1.  After adding a bit to your Toolbox, navigate to the bit dropdown menu above the preview pane in Easel. 

2.  Click on the bit you want to use for your project. 
![Choose bit to carve](https://inventablesprod.s3.amazonaws.com/general_images/features/mbc/MBC_Bits-6chooseinventablesbit-min.gif)
3.  If you are using a custom bit and/or material, make sure to input the cut settings for your bit. Feeds and speeds recommendations are often provided by the bit manufacturer. 

    a.  We have a [helpful article on understanding feeds and speeds](https://inventables.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/360012848433-Calculating-Your-Cut-Settings-Basic-Feeds-and-Speeds-Information) if you need help. You can also watch our [Carving Bits 101 Easel Live](https://inventables.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/360012849233-Carving-Bits-101-Bit-Basics) episode to learn more about different bit settings.

### Deleting a bit from your Toolbox

Remove a bit from your Toolbox to remove it from the bit drop-down menu near your project's cut settings.

Keep in mind that your Toolbox is linked to your account, not a specific project. This allows you to access your custom bits and materials across all your projects. Deleting a bit removes it from your Toolbox permanently. This will also remove it from your other project files.

1.  Click on the Easel icon in the top right corner to open the **Account** pop-up. Click on the **Toolbox** tab.

2.  Select **Bits** from the top navigation.

3.  Navigate to the bit you want to remove from your Toolbox. Click the arrow in the top right corner of the bit's image and click Delete. 

    a.  Once a bit is removed from your Toolbox, it is removed from your account and the bit drop-down menu near your project settings.

![Remove bit](https://inventablesprod.s3.amazonaws.com/general_images/features/mbc/MBC_Bits-7removebitsfromtoolbox-min.gif)

---

Adding Materials to Your Toolbox
--------------------------------

### Adding a custom material
Both Easel and Easel Pro users can add and save custom materials into their Toolbox. Easel Pro subscribers, Easel Pro day pass users, and Easel Pro free day users can carve with custom materials in their Toolbox.
1.  Once you're logged into Easel, click on the Easel icon in the top right corner to open the **Account** pop-up. Click on the **Toolbox** tab.

2.  Select **Materials** from the top navigation.

3.  Click the **Add Material** button in the top right corner.
![Add material](https://inventablesprod.s3.amazonaws.com/general_images/features/mbc/MBC_Bits-8navigatetomaterialschoosecustom-min.gif)
4.  Select *Custom* for the type of material you'd like to add. Type in a custom name for this material and choose the material type (Wood, Metal, Plastic). 
![](https://inventablesprod.s3.amazonaws.com/general_images/features/mbc/MBC_Bits-9addcustommaterial-min.gif)
5.  Click **Save** to add the material to your toolbox.

6.  Close the module when finished to navigate to your project. 

7.  Materials added to your Toolbox automatically appear in the material dropdown menu when you are choosing a material for your project.
  
 *Note: The rendering of custom materials will render as generic tones in the high-definition preview pane. At this time, textures and colors will not match custom materials. *

### Adding an Inventables material
Both Easel and Easel Pro users can add materials from the Inventables store into their Toolbox. Easel and Easel Pro users can carve with any Inventables materials in their Toolbox. 

1.  Log in to **Easel**.

2.  Navigate to your brand new **Toolbox** located in the **Project** pop-up.

3.  Make sure **Materials** is selected.

4.  Click **Add Materials** button in top right corner.

5.  Select *Inventables* for the type of material you'd like to add. Use the filter settings at the top to quickly locate your material. 
![Choose Inventables material](https://inventablesprod.s3.amazonaws.com/general_images/features/mbc/MBC_Bits-9-2chooseinventablesmaterial-min.gif)
6.  Click **Add Material** to add to your toolbox.

7.  Close the module when finished to navigate to your project. 

8.  Materials added to your Toolbox will show automatically in the material dropdown menu when you are choosing your project settings.
![Select material](https://inventablesprod.s3.amazonaws.com/general_images/features/mbc/MBC_Bits-9-3selectinventables material-min.gif)
*Note: Custom materials currently render as generic tones in the high-definition preview pane. At this time, textures and colors will not match custom materials.*

### Deleting a material from your Toolbox

Remove a custom material from your Toolbox to remove it from the material drop-down menu near your project's cut settings.

Your Toolbox is linked to your account, not a specific project. This allows you to access your custom bits and materials across all your projects. Deleting a custom material removes it from your Toolbox permanently. This will also remove it from your other project files.

1.  Click on the Easel icon in the top right corner to open the **Account** pop-up. Click on the **Toolbox** tab.

2.  Select **Materials** from the top navigation.

3.  Navigate to the material you want to remove from your Toolbox. Click the arrow in the top right corner of the material's image and click **Delete**. 
![Delete material](https://inventablesprod.s3.amazonaws.com/general_images/features/mbc/MBC_Bits-9-4deleteinventablesmaterialinproject-min.gif)
    a.  Once a custom material is removed from your Toolbox, it is removed from your account and the material drop-down menu near your project settings.

name: Easier g-code downloading
description:
The ability to download g-code has been moved from "Machine"->"General Settings" to the "Project" menu.

It will remain on the General Settings window for now but we hope its new location will be easier to find and use. In addition, multistage carves can now download as a zip file containing both g-code files. Users who wish to download the passes separately can also chose to do so. For assistance opening zip files see the following:

[Windows](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/zip-and-unzip-files-f6dde0a7-0fec-8294-e1d3-703ed85e7ebc) / [Mac](https://support.apple.com/guide/mac-help/zip-and-unzip-files-and-folders-on-mac-mchlp2528/mac)

name: Improved 3rd party machine setup
description:
Introducing a new streamlined process for adding 3rd party machines. You can now chose from an ever growing list of 3rd party makes and models. If your machine isn't listed please let us know in the feedback below.


####New machine setup workflow:

Step 1: Select "Other (3rd party machine)"

Step 2: Chose your machine's manufacturer.

Step 3: Chose your machine model, your machine's work area will automatically be set.

Step 4: Select "Confirm Settings"

Step 5: Test and configure any accessories.

![3rd_party_medium](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46683308/133823581-2ad348db-5239-440c-ad3a-30f56706ef52.gif)

---

Need to setup a machine that we don't currently list? Choose other and enter your machine's work area.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46683308/133824755-1efd7df4-7a4f-4dcd-bba0-c1990d25e899.png)

name: Machine Profiles
description:
For those of us with more than one CNC and / or computer, setting up CNCs can eat a lot of time. 

We'd like to fix that. We hope this system makes Easel Pro more helpful by letting you store your CNC configuration(s) on Inventables' servers and retrieve them as needed. Free users have access to one machine profile and can uninstall it to use a different machine. Adding multiple profiles is only available to pro users. 

## How it Works
1. Open the Machine tab in Easel
2. Click set up new machine and complete the setup steps.
3. Once set up, you can edit the name or other properties as well as uninstall it by clicking Edit your Machine.
4. Upon logging in from a different computer or new session, you can load your settings from the dropdown and skip the setup.
5. Easel Pro users will be able to set up multiple machine profiles and toggle loading between them by selecting it from the dropdown.

Note: if you have two machines of the same type (i.e. two x-carves) you may want to Edit their names to differentiate between them.

![animation of how it works](https://easel-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/features/machine_profiles/machine_profiles.gif)

### Included Settings
- Name
- Work area
- Spindle type
- Spindle control
- Spindle RPM
- Accessories
- Machine Type

Your saved cut settings will now be tied to specific machine profiles along with bit/material. That way you can differentiate different feeds and speeds for different machines.
formatted_description:
For those of us with more than one CNC and / or computer, setting up CNCs can eat a lot of time.

We'd like to fix that. We hope this system makes Easel Pro more helpful by letting you store your CNC configuration(s) on Inventables' servers and retrieve them as needed. Free users have access to one machine profile and can uninstall it to use a different machine. Adding multiple profiles is only available to pro users.

How it Works

  1. Open the Machine tab in Easel
  2. Click set up new machine and complete the setup steps.
  3. Once set up, you can edit the name or other properties as well as uninstall it by clicking Edit your Machine.
  4. Upon logging in from a different computer or new session, you can load your settings from the dropdown and skip the setup.
  5. Easel Pro users will be able to set up multiple machine profiles and toggle loading between them by selecting it from the dropdown.

Note: if you have two machines of the same type (i.e. two x-carves) you may want to Edit their names to differentiate between them.

Included Settings

  • Name
  • Work area
  • Spindle type
  • Spindle control
  • Spindle RPM
  • Accessories
  • Machine Type

Your saved cut settings will now be tied to specific machine profiles along with bit/material. That way you can differentiate different feeds and speeds for different machines.

name: Raster Fill
description:
Easel Pro users may now get a cleaner finish and better-looking carve when working with wood materials by choosing the Raster tool path strategy.
The Raster tool path strategy changes how the bit moves across your material when carving filled shapes in your project. Previously, Easel would always use the “offset” strategy, meaning it would typically start in the center of a filled area and gradually work its way to the edges, following the contours of your design. By contrast, with the Raster approach, Easel will move back and forth in a linear direction. 

The main advantage of the Raster strategy comes into play when working with woods. Because of how the bit moves linearly in parallel lines, using raster can help you follow the direction of the wood grain. By carving with the wood grain, you will see a much cleaner finish on the resulting carve.

To use this feature, open the cut settings panel and select a “Raster” direction:

![Raster settings](https://s3.amazonaws.com/inventablesprod/general_images/raster-single-bit.gif)

You can choose to have the raster direction move parallel with your X axis, or with your Y axis. The appropriate choice should be made based on which way you've mounted your workpiece on the wasteboard. If the grain of your wood is oriented horizontally, you should choose "X axis." If the grain of your wood is oriented vertically, you should choose "Y axis."

With a raster direction selected, all filled shapes will automatically be carved using a raster strategy for the corresponding workpiece.

If you are using two bits to do a roughing and detail pass, as in the gif below, you can pick the fill method that will be used for each bit:

![Raster 2 bits](https://s3.amazonaws.com/inventablesprod/general_images/raster-multi-bit.gif)

name: Tiling
description:
Carving large projects can be a hassle, but with tiling, Easel makes large projects easier.

##How it works
**In order to trigger tiling, you need to be carving a material bigger than your machine work area in the Y direction.**

A new tiling menu will appear in the material library dropdown in the top right screen in Easel. 

![Tiling Menu](https://easel-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/features/tiling/tiling-material-dropdown.png) 

Selecting a tile from the lengths shown will preview what Easel will carve in both the design and 3D preview panel. 

![Enable Tiling](https://easel-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/features/tiling/tiling-enabled.gif) 


##Using tiling
1. Make sure you've entered the correct size of your material.
2. Select the part of the design you wish to carve from the tiling menu *Tiling menu*
3. Use the preview to double-check which part of your design will carve.
4. Follow normal carving procedure.

> NOTE: If you are carving the nth tile, use the first step of the carve modal to see how much you should shift your material in order to carve the next tile.

##Prepping your material
1. Use material that can be aligned and shifted easily (straight left edge recommended)
2. Mark offsets shown in tile menu before starting the carve
3. Create a guard to slide material against. A 48" level can be used as a guide.
4. Reuse your last work position in the carve walkthrough when carving your second, third, etc. tiles

## Known Issues
- Even small deviations in the squareness of your CNC or material can result in tile carves not lining up perfectly. Square carefully!
- You must use tile overlap while V-Carving

name: Toolpath Ramping
formatted_description:
Easel Pro users now have the option to enable ramping for all shapes on a workpiece. Instead of a vertical plunge, the bit will ramp-in at the specified angle along the original toolpath. This behavior lowers the physical forces on a bit when it engages with the material, thus extending tool life and reducing the possibility of broken bits.

Ramping can be enabled under the "Cut Settings" menu for the current workpiece. We recommend using the 20° angle ramp for soft woods, plywood, and MDF like materials. The shallower 5° angle ramp is good for hardwoods and soft metals like aluminum.

 

Once enabled, ramping applies to all shapes that are in the current workpiece. This means both offset fill and raster fill pocket cuts as well as any outline cut.
